site.si_remarks: The data from trees in plots exposed to an atmospheric concentration 150 ppm higher than ambient since September 2012 have not been included. See refernce paper for further details on the methods.

plant.pl_remarks: Measurements are the average of two probes installed on the same tree at the same height in two different azimuth

stand.st_remarks: The upper soil (0-30) where most roots are located is classified as a 'LOAMY SAND' below 30-50 cm (actual depth depends on the exact location) there is a thin layer of semi-permeable dense clay and below that layer texture changes with depth. The % of sand, loam and caly given here are simply the mean of the upper 45 cm for the whole site.

env.env_remarks: Soil moisture was monitored with 8 probes per plot (ring). The values provied here are the mean of the three rings.

site.si_remarks: The study site is dominated by three eucalypt species representing a range of bark types: Eucalyptus obliqua L’Hér (deep fibrous ‘stringybark’), E. radiata Sieber ex DC (short fibrous ‘peppermint’ bark), and E. rubida H. Deane and Maiden (smooth ‘gum’ bark). The understorey is sparse and patchy, mainly consisting of native perennial grasses and Austral bracken (Pteridium esculentum (G.Forst.) Cockayne).

plant.pl_remarks: I used The HeatPulser, Edwards Industries, Taupo, NZ to measure transpiration rates, and had 4 probes installed along a sapwood gradient per stem. Each probe was corrected for deviations from exact parallel spacing of the heater and the thermistor elements, and wounding size was determined for all probes in November 2015. In addition, tree cores were collected next to each probe to correct measured sap velocities for gas and water fractions of the sapwood following Edwards and Warwick 1984.

site.si_remarks: Our study was conducted in a network of two altitudinal transects centered in the Lötschental , an inner-alpine valley located in the central Swiss Alps. The valley is enclosed by steep forested slopes (mostly >60%) primarily composed of mixed, evergreen Norway spruce and deciduous European larch extending to ∼2300 m a.s.l.

plant.pl_remarks: Sensors were installed in 2012 and continuously measuring until the end of 2015. A correction was applied to correction for signal dampening due to either the inward growth of the sensor or wounding effects. Sensors where installed on the slope-facing side of the tree.

stand.st_remarks: The soils along the transect are acidic and characterized by a large stone content and low amounts of clay. Different soil types were observed, ranging from Leptosol, Cambisolto Podzol, with intermediates. The soils were formed from calcareous-free parent material, including moraines and crystalline bedrock (gneiss and granite) from the Aar massif.

env.env_remarks: A radiation shield-covered sensor on a central tower was installed beneath the canopy to measure both air temperature (Ta; in addition to Onset, Tidbit mounted on trees at 1.6 m) and relative humidity (RH; Onset, U23-002 Pro; ~2.5 m above the ground). Soil moisture was measured hourly with 5 sensors at 10 and 70 cm depth per site (Decagon, EC-5). Solar irradiance was measured using a micro-station and pyrometer position on an open field in the valley bottom (Onset, H21-002 Micro Station and S-LIB-M003 respectively). Soil moisture measurements are expressed in %, while global radiation is provided in W/m^2.

stand.st_remarks: Canopy height is the average height of the dominant trees. If stand canopy height is desired, please average the heights described on the tab "plant_md".

env.env_remarks: Some measurements (net radiation and air temperature) had more than one sensor and placement within the canopy. The selected above are to capture the incident radiation above the overstory canopy and air temperature within the overstory canopy. Additionally, precip and VPD have different measurement timing (daily total and 30-min intervals, respecitvely). I have added to the end of the "environmental_hd" tab these data plus their respective timestamp. Rather than RH, we have vapor concentration at multiple heights, if needed. Only shallow SWC was provided since these parameter did not change within the first 20 cm and no other sensor was installed deeper than that. Please contact if any of these measurement placements should be altered or if there is any question regarding the precip and vpd data. Thanks!

plant.pl_remarks: The provided data includes period from 21/06/2007 to 16/10/2009.

site.si_remarks: Hedgerow olive orchard with regulated deficit irrigation

plant.pl_remarks: We don´t measure DBH because the canopy starts at very low height. The diameter provided were measured at 30-40 cm.  The plant leaf area is an average of each tree leaf area for the plot where the tree with sap flow sensor is located

stand.st_remarks: We have two very different soil layers: one going from 0 to 60 cm depth (77.7% sand, 2.2% silt and 20.1% clay) and another one going from 0 to 100 cm (60.9% sand, 2.0% silt and 37.1% clay). I introduced the data of the first layer in the cells because it´s where the roots are located mainly.

env.env_remarks: We have data for plant water potentials available for leaf: predawn and midday, xylem: midday and leaf: continuous (LPCP) but we could choose only one option. We measure soil water content at different depths (10, 20, 30, 40, 60, 100 cm) in and out of the irrigation bulb. We also have these measurements for both irrigation treatments

stand.st_remarks: We have two very different soil layers: one going from 0 to 60 cm depth (77.7% sand, 2.2% silt and 20.1% clay) and another one going from 0 to 100 cm (60.9% sand, 2.0% silt and 37.1% clay). I introduced the data of the first layer in the cells because it´s where the roots are located mainly.

env.env_remarks: We have data for plant water potentials available for leaf: predawn and midday, xylem: midday and leaf: continuous (LPCP) but we could choose only one option. We measure soil water content at different depths (10, 20, 30, 40, 60, 100 cm) in and out of the irrigation bulb. We also have these measurements for both irrigation treatments

stand.st_remarks: Relatively steep slope, ~30 %. Elevated soil stoniness (~19% gravel). Stand age is a rough estimation based on the likely cessationof coppicing after Civil War.

plant.pl_remarks: dictinction between sapwood and heartwood is not possible in Fagus sylvatica. To calculate tree sapflow from sapflux density we used a species-specific function (see Granier et al 2003. Deciduous forests: carbon and water fluxes, balances and ecophysiological determinants. Ecol. Stud. 163, 55–70.) that gives relative sap flux density as a function of depth below cambium

plant.pl_remarks: Data entered in sapflow_hd is at hourly time step eventhough the probes were collecting each 10 min. It was decided that due to small fluctuations with unknown origin, the hourly average was used in all publications using these data. NaN was used for gaps in datasets.

stand.st_remarks: The data is from planted evergreen needle trees -a native pine species- into an area formerly covered by deciduous broadleaf forests (cloud forest).

env.env_remarks: I also have within-canopy measurements but did not know how to add these here, so I left only the above canopy. The environmental parameters were actually collected at 10 min time steps but given that sapflow data was aggregated in hourly time steps, these were aggregated accordingly. Soil water content data is available but not included here as the principal data contributor was not available to provide it at hourly timesteps by the time of uploading this database. NaN was used for gaps in datasets.

plant.pl_remarks: Sapflow measurements actually start in 2009. First years suffer from instrument failures leaving large gaps. I decided to supply only the years 2012-2015. These years show also data gaps, mainly due to power shortage and mainly in winter and during nights. Therefore a window of 1 week has been used to determine Tmax. Sapwood area is calculated from DBH following Santi&Jans 1997. For sapwood area per hectare I have 2 numbers: 16.425 (Santi&Jans 1997) and 23.534 (Alex Soudant 2009). Sapflux supplied is per tree. Sapflux is calculated following Granier 1987. We have 6 trees instrumented with 2 sensors each, one on the North side and one on the South. The supplied data is an average of these two. Time stamps are at the END of the interval. Time is in CET, no summertime.

site.si_remarks: Site is dominated by the southern conifer Agathis australis. The leaves are not needle-shaped so I chose broadleaved forest for vegetation type but needle-leaved may be more appropriate if you want to make the conifer/angiosperm distinction. Michael Clearwater http://www.waikato.ac.nz/staff-profiles/people/mclearw is an additional contributor.

stand.st_remarks: The site is mixed-age with mature trees 500-800 years old and ricker (juvenile) trees that are suppressed beneath the canopy but are likely to be only decades old.

env.env_remarks: These are broad-leaf conifer trees

plant.pl_remarks: Sapwood depth and sapwood radial profile obtained by HFD method (multipoint sensors- 6 measurement points spaced 8-10 mm)

stand.st_remarks: Cork oak trees are debarked approximately every 9 years. Some of the studied trees should have been debarked during the experiment but they were not. The plot was fenced from 2006 onwards. Stand leaf area index was estimated from destructive sampling in one tree (QS4) and extrapolated to stand through canopy cover. Soil is deep Arenosol overlying a thick clay layer at 9m depth.

env.env_remarks: data loggers and periodical measurements were always programmed/referred to UT. Soil water measurements through echo probes (indicative, not very reliable). Data on groundwater level measured inside plot is available.

site.si_remarks: Elevation of site varies from 220 to 250 m asl. The mean value was given.                                            At this site different projects were run in different years and by different teams. This is the same site where Carboeuroflux Project was run.

plant.pl_remarks: Sapwood depth estimated based on multipoint HFD sensors applied in 2 Q. ilex rotundifolia trees: sapwood depth =outer 30% of stem radius

stand.st_remarks: The year previous to the experiment the study plot was fenced.                                      Canopy height is 7-8 m.                                                             Soil is a Dystric cambisoil overlying granite bedrock.                                      Stand age is approximate and was provided by the owner. Stand is dominated by Q. ilex rotundifolia though Q. suber appears in small scattered patches.

site.si_remarks: * study design was such that the influence of acacia longifolia (understory invader) on the water use of overstory pinus pinaster was evaluated. Sap flow was measured in 10 acacia and in 5 pinus growing with (trees lableled PAP#) and without (trees labeled PPP#) an acacia understory.

env.env_remarks: ** environmental variables were monitored at either 15 min or 60 minute intervals - it varied over the study.

site.si_remarks: There are only 2 months of data for this site. It is in a high latitude boreal forest that is roughly 100km from the boreal tree line. The growing season is short beginning in early-mid June. By the time the sapflow sensors were taken down on August 30, the leaves were turning yellow on most of the trees.

plant.pl_remarks: Sapflow was measured on the south and north side of 3 trees. Sapflow on the the south side was not significantly related to the north side, and the R2 of the relationship was 0.03. We did not apply any corrections due to the lack of a relationship and only calculate sapflow based on measurements on the north sensors.

site.si_remarks: The ecosystem is fire affected, but is later successional, so there are no direct fire effects during the measurement period. The site is on continuous permafrost. There is a paper describing this data currently in review.

plant.pl_remarks: We instrumented several trees at the site to test for azimuthal corrections and found no consistent patterns, therefore no corrections were made.

stand.st_remarks: Soils are gelisols charcterized by ~10cm thick peat rich organic soil layer, atop a clay rich mineral soil layer. The seasonally thawed active layer reaches approximately 0.7m depth.

env.env_remarks: The precipitation data are 3-hourly temporal resolution, collected from the Chersky airport, which is located ~5km from the study site. Also, the nevironmental data span the entire 3-year study period, including winter months with no sap-flow data.

site.si_remarks: Three different plots within 200 m from the Norunda flux tower. All sapflow data unpublished. In the winter of 2008/2009 part of the tower footprint was thinned.

stand.st_remarks: Measurements from a representative plot after thinning in winter 2008/2009. The soil is classified as a boulder-rich, sandy glacial till several meters deep. Dystric Regosols that consist of a thin organic layer a reddish B-horizon and a yellowish-gray C-horizon. Sandy loams containing many stones of all sizes up to 80 cm diameter. Fraction of fine material (<2mm) is only 30%! The stone content increases with depth. Below about 70 cm the soils are very compact with very few roots.The ground water table is highly variable.

site.si_remarks: Site was harvested approximately 25-30 prior to the study in 2004. The site captures a transition from upland aspen (Populus tremuloides) forest to a wetland dominated by white cedar (Thuja occidentalis). The elevation gradient is extremely subtle, and the sites is almost flat, but the water table is near the surface and wetlands are common in the area.

stand.st_remarks: There is a very high degree of heterogeneity in this stand, because it capture a fairly strong gradient. There are many small stems in the wetland portion that drive stem density up and basal area down.

env.env_remarks: There should be additional met data available from the WLEF flux tower. I downloaded data from the Fluxnet website, but it is only hourly resolution, so I did not include it here. In theory half hourly should be available though.

site.si_remarks: The forest was previously managed, and has remnants of a plantation. Also the site is within the footprint of the WLEF Ameriflux tower.

plant.pl_remarks: species specific sapwood area derived from previous studies in this area, leaf area derived from more general published species-specific allometric equations

site.si_name: PJSEV -Rainfall Manipulation Experiment - Sevilleta NWR, USA
site.si_remarks: A) Pinon-Juniper Experimental Rainfall Manipulation Experiment, B) Note; Recent disturbance has occured (in addition to drought) leading to whole tree mortality and/or significant canopy dieback due to biotic pest agents, including bark beetles (PIED), twig beetles (PIED), and stem boring beetles (JUMO).

plant.pl_remarks: A) Age unknown for Plot 4 trees, but many trees are at least 80+ years old based on coring of P4T3, which had a ground level pith date of 1930 CE, B) sapwood depth was not measured, but sensors were not installed in locations where heart wood was encountered during the installation process (sensors were installed at a depth of 0-10mm sapwood depth), C) tree leaf area and sapwood area were predicted using site specific allometric equations (see Pangle et al. 2015, Supplemental Note S2) and measurements of diameter (pl-dbh) at 30cm above ground level, D)  tree diameter (i.e., pl_dbh) was measured at 30cm above the root collar for both species, and for trees with multiple stems at ground level (mainly JUMO) - an equivalent stem diameter at 30cm height was calculated, E) For trees with multiple stems, sapflow was measured on differing stems or large branches of the same tree, F) the radial pattern of sapflow Js was assessed for a subset of trees and no significant decline in Js with sapwood depth was noted for either species, hence only Js rates from 0-10mm are reported (See Pangle et al. 2015, Supplemental Figure S2).

stand.st_remarks: A) Plot 4 is one of three ambient control plots in a larger experiment that included 12 plots in total, Plot4 is located in Replicate Block 1, B) Age data for trees in Plot 4 is sparse, however one PIED sapflow tree (P4T3) has been cored at the root collar and was determined to have an estimated pith date of 1930 CE,  B) stem density based on stems > 5.0 cm diameter (i.e., bole diameter or equivalent diameter if multi-stemmed)

env.env_remarks: A) The on-site meteorological station is located in an inter-canopy space (clearing) between experimental plots and environmental sensors were mounted at a height of 2-3 meters off the ground, B) Extensive soil VWC data is available for years 2007-2015 across plots 4 and 8 at soil depths of 5, 15/20, and 60 cm, Plot 12 only has VWC data for 5cm depth.  C)  Extensive predawn and midday foliar water potential data was also collected for each tree (across all plots) over a 10 year period starting in Year 2006.

plant.pl_remarks: A) Age for the majority of Plot 8 trees is well over 100+ years, with several individuals having an establishment date (tree ring analysis) before year 1850 CE, B) sapwood depth was not measured, but sensors were not installed in locations where heart wood was encountered during the installation process (sensors were installed at a depth of 0-10mm sapwood depth), C) tree leaf area and sapwood area were predicted using site specific allometric equations (see Pangle et al. 2015, Supplemental Note S2) and measurements of diameter (pl-dbh) at 30cm above ground level, D)  tree diameter (i.e., pl_dbh) was measured at 30cm above the root collar for both species, and for trees with multiple stems at ground level (mainly JUMO) - an equivalent stem diameter at 30cm height was calculated, E) For trees with multiple stems, sapflow was measured on differing stems or large branches of the same tree, F) the radial pattern of sapflow Js was assessed for a subset of trees and no significant decline in Js with sapwood depth was noted for either species, hence only Js rates from 0-10mm are reported (See Pangle et al. 2015, Supplemental Figure S2).

stand.st_remarks: A) Plot-8 is one of three ambient control plots in a larger experiment that included 12 plots in total, Plot-8 is located in Replicate Block 2, B) For select mature Pinon trees in Plot8, age is > 100+ years (determined from increment coring and tree ring analysis at root collar), C) stem density based on stems > 5.0 cm diameter (i.e., bole diameter or equivalent diameter if multi-stemmed), D) soil depth not determined at this time, but data should be available in late 2016

env.env_remarks: A) The on-site meteorological station is located in an inter-canopy space (clearing) between experimental plots and environmental sensors were mounted at a height of 2-3 meters off the ground, B) Extensive soil VWC data is available for years 2007-2015 across Plots 4 & 8 at soil depths of 5, 15/20, and 60 cm, Plot12 only has VWC data at 5cm depth,  C)  Extensive predawn and midday foliar water potential data was also collected for each tree (across all plots) over a 10 year period starting in Year 2006.

site.si_paper: Gush, M.B., Dzikiti, S., Clulow, A.D., Mengistu, M.G., Jarmain, C., Taylor, N.J. and Everson, C.S. 2014. Water use of apple orchards. In: Gush, M.B. and Taylor, N.J. (Eds) 2014. The water use of selected fruit tree orchards (Volume 2): Technical report on measurements and modelling. Water Research Commission Report No.1770/2/14, Section 3. WRC, Pretoria, RSA. (ISBN 978-1-4312-0575-2).
site.si_remarks: Field measurements were conducted in a 12-year old apple orchard (Malus domestica) at a commercial farm (“Nooitgedacht”) located near the town of Ceres in the Western Cape Province of South Africa (S33° 12’ 03.57”; E19° 20’ 15.06”; 1089 masl). The orchard was 134 m by 172 m (2.3 ha) in extent. It was planted to ‘Cripps’ Pink’ (‘Pink Lady’) apples on M793 rootstock, with every 8th tree in each row being a ‘Hillary’ crab-apple pollinator. Row orientation was north – south and the trees were spaced at 1.25 m by 4 m, giving a planting density of 2000 stems per ha, with a short grass cover between rows. Average tree height was 5.1 m and average stem diameter at 0.3 m from the base of the tree was 0.1 m. Irrigation water and fertiliser (‘fertigation’) were applied by means of short-range micro-sprinklers, with scheduling based on daily soil moisture and weather data. The discharge rate of each micro-sprinkler was 30 L.h¯¹, equivalent to 5 mm per hour for emitters which were positioned every 1.5 m within the tree rows. Soils were gravel, with a high sand and stone content, well drained and with an effective rooting depth of approximately 0.6 m. Annual orchard yields were 54 t.ha¯¹ in the 2008/2009 season and 69 t.ha¯¹ in the 2009/2010 season, with an average of 61.5 t.ha¯¹ over the two seasons.

plant.pl_remarks: Cripps' Pink' variety

env.env_remarks: Automatic Weather Station (AWS), conventional setup in clearing in vicinity of orchard (400m), sensors mounted at approximately 2m above ground, used in FAO-56 ETo (Allen et al, 1998) calculations.
